author: By Emily Flitter
title: Consumer Watchdog Wants Repeat Offender Banks Stripped of Licenses
description: Naming names, Rohit Chopra says big banks and other companies that break rules multiple times should face long-lasting consequences.
content: For the last two decades, the worst punishment that federal financial regulators seemed willing to impose was forcing companies caught repeatedly violating the law to admit they had done something wrong.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivek Shankar
title: Heineken and Carlsberg say they are leaving Russia.
description: The brewing giants are quitting Russia as companies face pressure to completely pull out of the country.
content: The Dutch brewer Heineken and its Danish rival Carlsberg said on Monday that they were getting out of Russia, moves that highlighted the pressure on multinational firms to go beyond pausing operations in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe
title: Shanghai’s lockdown
description: China’s largest outbreak since the beginning of the pandemic is now gripping Shanghai.
content: China’s largest outbreak since the beginning of the pandemic is now gripping Shanghai, its largest city and a global financial center.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Will Smith wins his first Oscar moments after hitting Chris Rock onstage.
description: “Richard Williams was a fierce defender of his family,” Smith said in his acceptance speech, referring to his role in “King Richard.”
content: Will Smith, who started his acting career in 1990 in an after-school special on ABC and became one of Hollywood’s most bankable and prolific action stars and producers, finally achieved the one thing that had always eluded him: He won an Oscar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Wapner
title: Cancer Patients Are at High Risk of Depression and Suicide, Studies Find
description: Two new studies of millions of people around the world suggest that doctors should be thinking more about cancer patients’ mental health, experts said.
content: One day years ago, during her training in neurology, Dr. Corinna Seliger-Behme met a man with end-stage bladder cancer. Before the diagnosis, the man had a stable family and job, and no history of mental health problems, Dr. Seliger-Behme recalled. But, soon after learning of his terminal disease, he tried to kill himself with a knife in the bathtub. He spent the last week of his life in the psychiatric ward.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mara Gay
title: There Are Solutions to New York’s High Rents Right in Front of Us
description: New York needs more housing fast, and a few key measures would help build it.
content: Rents in New York City are soaring. Even upper-middle-class New Yorkers are finding they are unable to afford to buy homes in the communities they grew up in. Poor and working-class New Yorkers are staring down homelessness. Thousands of eviction proceedings are underway across the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo and Ian Austen
title: Pope Meets With Groups Requesting Apology for Indigenous Schools
description: For the first time, Francis received Indigenous survivors of abusive boarding schools in Canada who were seeking the pontiff’s apology over the church’s role in running the schools.
content: VATICAN CITY — Pope Francis on Monday held his first Vatican meeting with Indigenous groups from Canada who were seeking his apology over the Roman Catholic Church’s involvement in a system of boarding schools that abused Indigenous children for over 100 years.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: March 28, 2022
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, March 28, 2022.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: Will the Buffalo Bills Get a $1.4 Billion Stadium?
description: Gov. Kathy Hochul is eager to keep the football team from leaving town.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at how far New York State might go to help build a new stadium for the Buffalo Bills. We’ll also look at a play that’s coming to Off Broadway and tells the story of a Dreamer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: This Simple Colombian Beef and Potato Soup Is Full of Possibility
description: Caldo de costilla, a popular pick-me-up, makes a simple and satisfying dinner that becomes blank canvas for leftovers, J. Kenji López-Alt writes.
content: The first time I had caldo de costilla was at the wedding of my sister-in-law, Ana-Maria, in Bogotá, Colombia. As midnight rolled around, I figured the grandparents, great-aunts and great-uncles who led the charge on the dance floor might have finally tired of salsa and bachata; in my 20s at the time, even I was starting to feel the effects of drinking anise-scented aguardiente and dancing all night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Women’s N.C.A.A. Tournament: What to Watch as Final Four Is Determined
description: The final two spots for the women’s Final Four are up for grabs.
content: The last two teams for the women’s Final Four will be decided on Monday night in Bridgeport, Conn., and Wichita, Kan. The lineup includes the Connecticut Huskies, who have been to the past 13 national semifinals. The other three teams have much more to prove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Aaron Krolik
title: When Nokia Pulled Out of Russia, a Vast Surveillance System Remained
description: The Finnish company played a key role in enabling Russia’s cyberspying, documents show, raising questions of corporate responsibility.
content: Nokia said this month that it would stop its sales in Russia and denounced the invasion of Ukraine. But the Finnish company didn’t mention what it was leaving behind: equipment and software connecting the government’s most powerful tool for digital surveillance to the nation’s largest telecommunications network.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Priya Krishna
title: A Fast, Frugal Track to a Cook’s Career? Community College.
description: As culinary programs dwindle and restaurants hunt for help, these local campuses are adding state-of-the-art cooking schools at a friendly price.
content: HAVERHILL, Mass. — The students all wore white chef coats, houndstooth pants and short toques as they tasted their lamb tagines for salt. Floor-to-ceiling windows in the sleek kitchen framed a sweeping view of the Merrimack River.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $2.4 Million Homes in California
description: A three-bedroom co-op in San Francisco, a midcentury ranch house in San Anselmo and a 1914 Spanish-style home in San Diego.
content: This apartment is in Union Terrace, designed by the Scottish-born architect T. Paterson Ross, who was also responsible for the Red Cross building at the Presidio and the Union League Club, where he died in a construction accident in 1922. The style was inspired by traditional pueblo homes, with terra-cotta flourishes and a central courtyard, and the units were situated to take advantage of the views: Alcatraz Island, Angel Island and the Art Institute complex are visible from the private roof decks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor and Johnny Diaz
title: Snow Squall Leads to 50-Car Pileup on Pennsylvania Highway
description: Several tractor-trailers were involved in the chain-reaction crash on Interstate 81, about 50 miles northeast of Harrisburg, Pa. The wreckage extended for about a mile, the authorities said.
content: A blinding snow squall led to a fiery pileup on a Pennsylvania interstate on Monday morning that involved at least 50 vehicles, including several tractor-trailers, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Ariana DeBose becomes the first openly queer woman of color to win an acting Oscar.
description: DeBose is also the first openly queer woman of color to win an acting Oscar.
content: Ariana DeBose won the Oscar for best supporting actress for her role as Anita in Steven Spielberg’s adaptation of “West Side Story.” It is her first Academy Award. The outcome was expected but historic nonetheless as the 31-year-old actress becomes only the second Latina to nab an Oscar. The first one was Rita Moreno, who won in 1962 for the same role in the original film version. DeBose is also the first openly queer star to win an acting Oscar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jenny Vrentas and Ken Belson
title: Brian Flores’s Lawsuit Looms Over N.F.L. Owners Meetings
description: At its annual meeting, the league announced plans to increase diverse hiring practices, as John Mara, the Giants’ co-owner, called Flores’s claims of discrimination “false.”
content: PALM BEACH, Fla. — The N.F.L. team owners are grappling with several weighty issues at the league’s annual meeting this week that clash with the setting at the posh Breakers Hotel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Manohla Dargis and A.O. Scott
title: Does the Academy Hold Movies in Contempt? Our Critics Wonder.
description: Whatever you make of the slap, the telecast as a whole was a frustrating night of television that seemed based on a misunderstanding of what makes films great.
content: Our chief film critics reflect on an Oscar night that went pretty much as expected — until it didn’t.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Paulson
title: ‘Camelot’ Is Returning to Broadway, Reimagined by Aaron Sorkin
description: The Lincoln Center Theater production, with a new book by Sorkin and directed by Bartlett Sher, will open in December.
content: Lincoln Center Theater said Monday that it would stage a revival of the classic musical “Camelot” on Broadway this fall, with a new book by the screenwriter Aaron Sorkin.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Kaplan
title: Bobcats With a Taste for Python Eggs Might Be the Guardians of Florida’s Swamp
description: Cameras captured the wild feline purloining a Burmese python’s eggs, giving hope that the state’s native species are responding to a voracious, invasive predator.
content: The voracious appetite of the invasive Burmese python is causing Florida’s mammal and bird populations to plummet. With little natural competition to control the big snake’s numbers, the situation looks desperate. But new observations suggest that the bobcat, a wildcat native to Florida, might be able to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: New Supply Chain Risk: 22,000 Dockworkers Who May Soon Strike
description: With the contract of union workers at West Coast ports nearing expiration, the prospect of a labor impasse threatens another shock to the global economy.
content: In a world contending with no end of economic troubles, a fresh source of concern now looms: the prospect of a confrontation between union dockworkers and their employers at some of the most critical ports on earth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: General Strike Throws India Into Confusion
description: The two-day strike, involving both public and private sector workers, was called to protest the Modi government’s economic policies, including a privatization plan.
content: A two-day nationwide strike called by hundreds of thousands of workers to protest government economic policies has  spread to large parts of India, with supporters of the walkout blocking roads and train tracks, and public transportation absent from the streets of many towns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margot Sanger-Katz
title: Missing From Biden’s Budget: His Signature Policy Agenda
description: The Build Back Better package that has consumed Congress for months was relegated to the footnotes.
content: Administrations normally detail their biggest policy dreams in their annual budgets. The Biden administration tucked its into the footnotes instead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vanessa Friedman
title: A New Generation Changes the Oscar Red Carpet Rules
description: Timothée Chalamet, shirtless; Kristen Stewart in hot pants. Can we finally say goodbye to the mermaid dress and penguin suit?
content: It’s hard to remember now, through the mist of time, but there was a moment, pre-Covid, when a movement was afoot in Hollywood to #askhermore on the red carpet (him too). To try to change what was looking, literally, like a paid-for marketing opportunity for fashion, and the celebs that wore it, into a storytelling opportunity about values and personal choice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Weigh California Law on Humane Treatment of Pigs
description: Trade groups challenged the law, which requires adequate space for breeding pigs to turn around, saying it unfairly burdens out-of-state farmers.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to hear a challenge to a California law that seeks to address cruelty to animals by requiring that pork sold in the state come from breeding pigs housed in spaces that allow them to move around freely.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Biden Renews Pushback Against Stock Buybacks
description: Proposed new limits come as corporations may spend $1 trillion on stock repurchases this year.
content: When the Biden administration unveils its annual budget today, it will propose new ways to raise money from big companies and wealthy executives. One of these ideas could rewrite a fundamental practice in corporate America: stock buybacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kurt Streeter
title: The N.C.A.A. Undervalued Women’s Basketball. Marketers Didn’t.
description: The N.C.A.A. had to confront its inequitable handling of its Division I women’s tournament. This year, the women are enjoying an endorsement windfall.
content: SPOKANE, Wash. — No one here could escape the symbolism. March Madness logos seemed to be everywhere in this small city last week, on posters, stickers, towels, electronic billboards and in hotel lobbies. The madness had come to this and the three other cities hosting the final 16 teams in the N.C.A.A. women’s basketball tournament.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rax Will
title: When ‘Sir’ and ‘Ma’am’ Miss the Mark: Restaurants Rethink Gender’s Role in Service
description: A dinner out can be discomforting for nonbinary and transgender people. But efforts are afoot to change that.
content: LOS ANGELES — As Anaelia Ovalle stood outside a restaurant here deciding whether to go in, the host extended a friendly greeting: “Hello, sir.” But the phrase didn’t feel all that welcoming to Ovalle, 27, who identifies as nonbinary and uses the pronouns “they” and “them.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jay Caspian Kang
title: The Slums of California
description: Temporary units for the homeless might sound good, but where does one go from there?
content: Nearly everyone in California has an opinion about the homelessness crisis, but very few people have a realistic vision of what to do about it. In the Bay Area and Los Angeles, where thousands of people sleep on the streets or in tent encampments every night, one of the more popular proposals has been to build many new units of temporary shelter. These take many forms: tiny-home villages that provide a shed-size house for two residents, repurposed hotel rooms and “Safe Sleep” sites where people can move into tents. The idea is to continue to scatter these various units throughout mostly low-income areas of cities, especially those that have been overtaken by unofficial homeless encampments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: From Kind Bars to Vegan Mexican Food
description: Somos, from the founders of Kind Healthy Snacks, have introduced this line of snacks, sides and ready-to-heat preparations.
content: Daniel Lubetzky, the founder of Kind Healthy Snacks, the maker of fruit- and nut-based snack bars — now owned by the Mars company — and other executives have introduced Somos. The line of ready-to-heat vegan preparations, entrees and sides are made in Mexico. Pouches of meatless picadillo made with potatoes and peas; cauliflower tinga in a robust sauce; mushrooms in chipotle sauce; and beans and rice can take to the stove top or microwave. Also available are white corn tortillas and four salsas, of which the brooding, roasted tomatillo pasilla was my favorite. Their “Unusually Thick and Crunchy White Corn Tortilla Chips” have a crisp yet substantial texture and slightly smoky flavor. Individual items are $2.99 to $5.29; kits for assembling quesadillas, tacos and so forth, including one for Cinco de Mayo, are $32 to $60.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Administrative note: Hello Hivemind! We’re very excited to announce a new Spelling Bee feature, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.” Deb Amlen, a Wordplay columnist and senior editor of our section, will take you through her thoughts on the previous week’s puzzles. The new feature will publish every Saturday, and a link to it will be included in the following Monday’s edition of Spelling Bee Forum. The first edition can be found here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Putin and the Myths of Western Decadence
description: Are we losing the traditional values that really matter?
content: Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine was, first and foremost, a crime — indeed, the war crimes continue as you read this. But it was also a blunder. In less than five weeks Putin has destroyed Russia’s military reputation, battered his nation’s economy and strengthened the democratic alliances he hoped to undermine. How could he have made such a catastrophic mistake?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Soloski
title: Review: In Stefano Massini’s ‘7 Minutes,’ It’s Make or Break
description: The author of “The Lehman Trilogy” sets his new work in a fictional textiles factory, where workers debate in real time the new owners’ demands.
content: Though based on real events, “7 Minutes,” produced by Waterwell in association with Working Theater, is a piece of hopeful fantasy. It envisions a roomful of people in profound disagreement. Despite disparities of attitude and background, these people listen, respectfully, to one another’s arguments. In our increasingly partisan society, “7 Minutes” offers a portrait of representative democracy — functional, unmired — in action. Can you believe it?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
title: Federal Judge Finds Trump Most Likely Committed Crimes Over 2020 Election
description: “The illegality of the plan was obvious,” the judge wrote in a civil case. Separately, the Jan. 6 panel voted to recommend contempt of Congress charges for two former Trump aides.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal judge ruled on Monday that former President Donald J. Trump and a lawyer who had advised him on how to overturn the 2020 election most likely had committed felonies, including obstructing the work of Congress and conspiring to defraud the United States.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling, Matt Stevens and Julia Jacobs
title: Will Smith Apologizes to Chris Rock After Academy Condemns His Slap
description: “I was out of line and I was wrong,” said Smith, who hit Rock at the Oscars after the comedian made a joke about his wife. The film organization opened an inquiry into the incident.
content: LOS ANGELES — Will Smith apologized to the comedian Chris Rock on Monday evening for slapping him during Sunday night’s Oscars telecast after the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences, which administers the awards, denounced his actions and opened an inquiry into the incident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Fishwife and Fly by Jing Join Forces
description: The companies have teamed up for perfectly piquant cans of smoked salmon with Sichuan chile crisp.
content: Yes, you could toss hot smoked salmon with Chinese chile crisp yourself. But Becca Millstein, a founder of the domestic tinned seafood company Fishwife, and Jing Gao, the owner of the Chinese condiments and dumpling company Fly by Jing, joined forces to make this winning combination for you. They share office space, so a collaboration came naturally. Their new smoked salmon fillets canned with Sichuan chile crisp are properly piquant; serve tossed with scallions and blanched snow peas, or over rice or noodles, among other options.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater
title: Jan. 6 Panel Is Likely to Seek Interview With Ginni Thomas
description: The committee is preparing to reach out to the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas after the disclosure of her text messages supporting efforts to overturn the election.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol is likely to reach out soon to Virginia Thomas, the wife of Justice Clarence Thomas, to request that she sit for an interview, according to two people familiar with the matter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Alan Rappeport and Emily Cochrane
title: Biden’s $5.8 Trillion Budget Pivots Toward Economic and Security Concerns
description: The president released his latest budget proposal amid war in Ukraine and concerns at home about rising costs.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday proposed a $5.8 trillion budget that includes significant increases in funding for the military and police departments, along with higher taxes on corporations and the wealthiest Americans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Zornosa and Melena Ryzik
title: Billie Eilish and Finneas win their first Oscar with ‘No Time to Die.’
description: Their victory came for the theme song from the James Bond film of the same name. The previous two Bond themes also won Oscars.
content: “No Time to Die,” from the James Bond film of the same name, took home the Oscar for best song. The accolade is the first Oscar win for Billie Eilish and Finneas, the brother and sister team who co-wrote the track. The song made Eilish the youngest artist ever to record a Bond theme.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By ‘Sway'
title: Why Facebook’s ‘Hubris and Arrogance’ Astound This Attorney General
description: Attorney General Maura Healey of Massachusetts weighs in on social media, the Sacklers and Florida’s “Don’t Say Gay” bill.
content: Attorney General Maura Healey of Massachusetts has sued the Trump administration, Uber, Juul, Exxon Mobil, the Sacklers and more — and has made a national name for herself in the process. Now she’s investigating social media companies for the impact they have on teen mental health, and she’s not impressed. “The level of hubris and arrogance, particularly on the part of Facebook, has really astounded me,” she tells Kara Swisher.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Would Putin Strike NATO Supply Lines to Ukraine? History Suggests No.
description: From the Soviets in Afghanistan to the U.S. in Korea, Moscow and Washington have often chosen not to attack the countries aiding their enemies.
content: WASHINGTON — A Russian missile strike on Sunday in western Ukraine near the Polish border, which has become a transit point for weapons being sent to Ukrainian forces, raised new concerns about whether Russia might attack NATO territory to stop or destroy the shipments.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: Your Monday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: What Is Alopecia?
description: Jada Pinkett Smith’s hair loss condition played a major role in an incident at the Oscars. Here’s what we know about it.
content: Last night at the Oscars, Will Smith slapped Chris Rock after the comedian made a joke at the expense of Smith’s wife, Jada Pinkett Smith, who is experiencing hair loss.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Desiree Ibekwe
title: How ‘Bridgerton’ Touches on Colonialism in India
description: Season 2 of the Netflix show centers on the Sharma family, whose story of moving between England and India has echoes in historical fact.
content: This article contains spoilers for Season 2 of “Bridgerton.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Scott Tobias
title: Where to Stream ‘CODA,’ ‘Dune’ and More 2022 Oscar Winners
description: All of the night’s winners can be watched at home. Here’s a guide to help you find the honorees.
content: The memorably turbulent 94th Academy Awards on Sunday ended with the Sundance favorite “CODA” winning best picture, capping a triumphant night in which it collected awards in all three of its nominated categories. It’s also the first time a streaming platform has won the top prize at the Oscars, representing a history-making victory for Apple, which is offering the film exclusively on Apple TV+. Other winners are available on subscription services, too, like Netflix’s “The Power of the Dog”; and “Dune,” which can only be streamed on HBO Max, though it can be bought on other sites. The rest of the films are a browser window away from this list.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley and Lara Jakes
title: Israeli Summit Mixes Historic Symbolism With Sharp Disputes
description: The meeting of diplomats from Israel, the U.S. and four Arab countries was momentous just for taking place. But in private, they tried to hash out differences over Iran and the war in Ukraine.
content: SDE BOKER, Israel — For all its powerful geopolitical symbolism, the first-ever multilateral Arab-Israeli summit on Israeli soil was a largely transactional affair.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: With a Center-Leaning Budget, Biden Bows to Political Reality
description: The president’s budget addresses the main attack lines that Republicans are using against him and his Democratic allies in Congress in the run-up to the midterm congressional elections.
content: WASHINGTON — With his party facing potentially gale-force headwinds in the midterm elections, President Biden on Monday tacked toward the political center with a budget that would bolster military and law enforcement spending while tackling inflation and deficit reduction in service of what he called a “bipartisan unity agenda.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Bryan Avelar
title: Explosion of Gang Violence Grips El Salvador, Setting Record
description: Gangs went on a killing spree, gunning down anyone on the street. At least 62 were killed on Saturday, the deadliest day on record since the country’s civil war ended 30 years ago.
content: El Salvador declared a state of emergency Sunday after gangs went on a killing spree on Saturday, randomly shooting street vendors, bus passengers and marketgoers. It was the single bloodiest day in the country on record since the end of its civil war 30 years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: How Do You Feel About Another Coronavirus Wave?
description: Tell us how you’re approaching a possible BA.2 surge.
content: It seems like the Omicron wave just let up and already epidemiologists are telling Americans to brace for another surge — this time from the fast-moving BA.2 subvariant. The possibility of a new surge comes with fresh uncertainty — and the virus continues to surprise us at every turn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní
title: Buffalo Bills Strike Deal for Taxpayer-Funded $1.4 Billion Stadium
description: The agreement calls for $850 million in New York State and local funding, the largest taxpayer contribution ever for a National Football League facility.
content: ALBANY, N.Y. — New York State officials have reached a deal with the Buffalo Bills to use $850 million in public funds to help the team build a $1.4 billion stadium — the largest taxpayer contribution ever for a pro football facility.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Beinart
title: The Friend of Our Enemy Is Not a ‘Traitor’
description: Why we shouldn’t call critics of America’s “war” on Putin traitors.
content: It’s an old story: In times of war, antiwar voices are labeled disloyal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Biden proposes a tax on billionaires as he looks to fund his economic agenda.
description: The new tax would apply to the richest Americans and would target unrealized capital gains.
content: President Biden on Monday proposed raising taxes on the wealthiest Americans and corporations, outlining several initiatives in his 2023 budget aimed at bringing down the federal budget deficit and closing loopholes that allow the rich to lower their tax bills.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: A Violinist Rethinks Her Devotion to Music, With Emotion and Erudition
description: In “Uncommon Measure,” a genre-defying memoir, Natalie Hodges writes about the years of her young life spent in classical music.
content: Children who were pressured to play classical music form, in adulthood, a kind of secret society. They share weary nods of mutual recognition and a specialized language, knowing for example that “classical” more accurately refers to the period between Baroque and Romantic than formal and high-class; the meaning of solfège (think “Do-Re-Mi,” hours of it, without the pretty scenery); and that pieces without words should not be referred to as “songs.” Instead of Little Leaguer’s elbow, they might have had fiddler’s neck, a bruise on the side of the throat “that resembles a very ardent hickey,” as Natalie Hodges, a longtime violinist and superb representative of this society, explains it: “that badge of pride, won only after years of consistent practice.” (To some this is more a badge of embarrassment.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Best and Worst Moments of the 2022 Oscars
description: The night made history, from That Slap to milestone wins by Troy Kotsur and Ariana DeBose, and a rousing performance by Beyoncé.
content: The 94th Academy Awards will forever be known for one, did-that-just-happen moment: Will Smith slapping Chris Rock after the comedian made a joke about his wife. That was probably not on anyone’s Oscars bingo card. Instead, going into the evening, there was mostly uncertainty: What would the ceremony do to acknowledge the Russian invasion of Ukraine? How would three hosts work, especially after going without even one since 2018? And would the telecast be more entertaining — possibly even shorter — if several awards were moved to a preshow? Here are the highs and lows as we saw them. — Stephanie Goodman
source.name: The New York Times

author: By André Wheeler
title: Behind Beyoncé’s Viral Oscars Dress
description: David Koma, the Georgian designer, explains what goes into making a costume befit for a pop star.
content: Hours before Will Smith slapped Chris Rock, Beyoncé delivered the first major Oscars moment of the night. The singer opened the 94th Academy Awards on Sunday with her highest-profile televised performance in nearly two years. Beyoncé transformed a tennis court in Compton, Calif. (where the tennis greats Venus and Serena Williams trained as children) into a tableau of neon-yellow and Black pride.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Virginia Hughes
title: Does Social Media Make Teens Unhappy? It May Depend on Their Age.
description: A large study in Britain found two specific windows of adolescence when some teenagers are most sensitive to social media.
content: Over the past few years, as the cold glow of a smartphone has followed more and more adolescents from bedroom to school and back again, parents have fretted over the technology’s influence. And no wonder, with Facebook researchers covertly studying how its apps erode girls’ body image, doctors describing TikTok-induced tic disorders, and prosecutors and lawmakers pledging to hold social media companies responsible for harming children.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Motoko Rich
title: ‘Drive My Car’ Oscar Is a Slow-Burn Return for Japan’s Cinema
description: But some of the same qualities that made the film popular overseas have led to a cooler reception domestically.
content: TOKYO — The last time a Japanese entry won the Oscar for best international film 13 years ago, it was something of an upset, surprising the forecasters who had barely heard of “Departures,” Yojiro Takita’s story about an accidental undertaker, before the ceremony.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sean T. Collins
title: ‘Billions’ Season 6, Episode 10 Recap: The Dragon’s Heart
description: Neither Chuck nor Prince has really moved on, even if everyone around them seems ready to.
content: There’s a valedictory note in the air. It starts in the office of the New York state attorney general, where Chuck’s newly minted replacement, Dave Mahar, leads a send-off toast to her ex-boss. It is echoed in an all-hands meeting called by Mike Prince, held at his own home — a meeting that turns into a booze and molly-fueled dance party D.J.ed by Questlove.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: Reducing Covid’s Toll
description: Many experts expect Covid caseloads to rise soon. Here are four steps to protect people.
content: The BA.2 subvariant — an even more contagious version of Omicron — has already caused Covid-19 cases to rise across much of Europe. In the U.S., caseloads have held steady over the past week, ending two months of sharp declines, and many experts expect increases soon.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Poniewozik
title: An Onstage Slap Gives the Oscars More Drama Than It Bargained For
description: The show strained to offer something for everyone. But it could still create shocking moments.
content: The theme of the 2022 Oscars was “Movie Lovers Unite.” For Chris Rock and Will Smith, the reunion was more dramatic — and painful — than the academy could have planned or wanted.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Troy Kotsur makes history as the first deaf man to win an acting Oscar.
description: “This is dedicated to the deaf community, the CODA community and the disabled community,” he said in his acceptance speech, delivered in American Sign Language. “This is our moment.”
content: In an important step for representation in Hollywood, Troy Kotsur became the first deaf man in academy history to win an Oscar for acting. Voters honored his heartstring-tugging supporting performance in “CODA” as a fisherman struggling to relate to his hearing daughter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: DeSantis Signs Florida Bill That Opponents Call ‘Don’t Say Gay’
description: The law has drawn criticism from the White House, Disney employees and Hollywood. The governor has dismissed opponents as “woke.”
content: MIAMI — Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida signed legislation on Monday that prohibits classroom instruction and discussion about sexual orientation and gender identity in some elementary school grades, a law that opponents have called “Don’t Say Gay.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeremy W. Peters
title: Rumble, the Right’s Go-To Video Site, Has Much Bigger Ambitions
description: The company, supported by Donald Trump, Peter Thiel and other prominent conservatives, wants to help build a “new internet” independent from Silicon Valley’s titans.
content: You won’t find Red Pill News or the X22 Report on YouTube anymore. The far-right online shows were taken down in the fall of 2020 after the major social media and tech companies started purging accounts that spread the QAnon conspiracy theory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Administration moves to make funding for Indian Health Service mandatory.
description: The budget request for the Indian Health Service calls for increasing the agency’s budget to $9.1 billion, a more than 20 percent increase from the previous funding level.
content: The White House unveiled on Monday a significant proposed shift in the way the Indian Health Service was funded as part of its 2023 budget, proposing the health care agency move from discretionary to mandatory funding.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Alan Rappeport
title: Biden Aims to Boost Military and Social Spending in 2023 Budget
description: The president will unveil his latest budget proposal amid a war in Ukraine and concerns at home about rising costs.
content: Follow our live coverage of President Biden’s budget proposal for 2023.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Sperling
title: Inside the 2022 Oscar Governors Ball
description: Will Smith skipped the party, but Jessica Chastain, Ariana DeBose and Billie Eilish did a victory lap.
content: The Governors Ball is the first stop of the final night of an exhausting and bitter award season, where nominees, both winners and losers, can finally breathe, thankful that their months of staying on brand and on message has come to a close.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melinda Wenner Moyer
title: Women Are Calling Out ‘Medical Gaslighting’
description: Studies show female patients and people of color are more likely to have their symptoms dismissed by medical providers. Experts say: Keep asking questions.
content: Jenneh Rishe could easily run six miles in under 45 minutes — until suddenly she couldn’t. In the spring of 2019, Mrs. Rishe, now 35, began finding her daily jogs a struggle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Panel Makes Case for Contempt Charges for 2 Former Trump Aides
description: The House committee investigating the Capitol riot issued a report on Peter Navarro and Dan Scavino Jr.’s roles in efforts to overturn Donald Trump’s election loss.
content: WASHINGTON — The House committee investigating the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol released a report on Sunday laying out reasons to charge two allies of former President Donald J. Trump with criminal contempt of Congress for their participation in efforts to overturn the 2020 election and their subsequent refusal to comply with the panel’s subpoenas.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Proulx
title: Reading Poetry With the Poem Column
description: In this lesson, we invite students to read a poem selected by New York Times editors, then find their own poem and write about what it means to them.
content: Featured Column: Poem
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tiffany Hsu
title: 94th Academy Awards Beats Last Year’s Lowest-Ever Oscars Ratings
description: Even with a marked rebound in viewership, the 2022 Oscars was the second-least-watched year for the awards show.
content: The Academy Awards on Sunday night drew a larger audience than last year, when viewership plunged to an all-time low, but interest remained depressed amid disruptions to television- and movie-watching habits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gail Collins and Bret Stephens
title: Ted Cruz Knows Which Side He’s On
description: Washington is getting extra serious and extra silly.
content: Bret Stephens: Hi, Gail. I think many Americans would give President Biden reasonably high marks for his handling of the war in Ukraine so far. His speech in Poland, in which he said, “For God’s sake, this man cannot remain in power,” may have been provocative, and it might have his advisers scrambling to soften it, but it was right, and the right message to send about what should become of Vladimir Putin’s foul regime.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffery C. Mays
title: Will Black Democratic Voters Turn Out for Gov. Hochul?
description: Black political leaders support the governor, but there are signs of a lack of fervor and lingering support for Andrew Cuomo among Black voters.
content: From the moment she took office, Gov. Kathy Hochul set out to shore up her standing with an important constituency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Marco Rubio Leads G.O.P. Push for a More Combative Stance on China
description: It’s time for Americans to buckle down for a long struggle with Beijing, the Florida senator will argue in a speech.
content: Marco Rubio wants Americans to “wake up.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Maison Jar, in Brooklyn, Follows the Lead of French Packaging-Free Stores
description: The Greenpoint “refillery” stocks food products, pet food and household essentials in bulk.
content: When Larasati Vitoux, who is from Orléans, France, returned there a few years ago she was struck by the number of packaging-free stores, or épiceries en vracs. Seeing a need in New York, where she lives, she has opened Maison Jar in Greenpoint, Brooklyn. Just about everything is sold in bulk, by weight and self-service, so customers bring their own containers. (Customers can purchase jars.) This “refillery,” as Ms. Vitoux calls it, stocks food products, cleaning supplies and other essentials, many dispensed from silos. Breads from sources like She Wolf, fresh produce, and soon, cheeses cut to order will also available. In keeping with her eco-friendly philosophy, many of the products are organic.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney says it hopes Florida anti-L.G.B.T.Q. law is repealed or ‘struck down by the courts.’
description: Disney’s employees criticized the company this month for not taking a public stance against the legislation.
content: Moments after Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida signed an anti-L.G.B.T.Q. bill into law on Monday, Disney released a statement condemning it and saying that its “goal as a company is for this law to be repealed by the legislature or struck down by the courts.” Disney employs roughly 80,000 people in the Orlando area.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Why It’s So Difficult to Assess Pandemic Risks Right Now
description: Californians have more decisions to make about how to deal with Covid-19 than ever before.
content: California in recent weeks has inched away from its strictest pandemic policies, lifting its indoor mask mandates and some vaccination requirements. The state last month released a long-term plan for living with the coronavirus, instead of treating it as an emergency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sadiba Hasan
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘How to Survive a Pandemic’ and the Grammy Awards
description: A documentary about the race for the Covid-19 vaccine airs on HBO. And this year’s Grammy Awards are on CBS.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, March 28-April 3. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Renkl
title: The Boring Bill in Tennessee That Everyone Should Be Watching
description: Republicans are about freedom and small government only when they’re not the ones in control of the government.
content: NASHVILLE — When a new energy infrastructure bill was introduced in the Tennessee General Assembly earlier this month, people could be forgiven for paying little attention. Compared to the legislature’s recent follies — an abortion bill that would out-Texas Texas, or a book-banning bill that would override the recommendations of school librarians, or a handgun bill that would let 18-year-olds carry a gun without a permit — an energy-infrastructure bill seems like a big yawn.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: Sara Suleri Goodyear Dies at 68; Known for Memoir of Pakistan
description: Her 1989 book, “Meatless Days,” is viewed as an important work of postcolonial literature.
content: Sara Suleri Goodyear, a scholar who vividly evoked her upbringing in Pakistan in “Meatless Days,” a 1989 memoir often cited as a foundational work of post-colonial literature, died on March 20 at her home in Bellingham, Wash. She was 68.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tania Ganguli
title: Kyrie Irving Makes His Brooklyn Return
description: With new vaccine rules in place, the Nets can finally play their star guard at Barclays Center.
content: Kyrie Irving basked in it — a crowd eager for his return, and his belief that he had won the battle he fought this season against vaccine mandates. When asked about the game, after Sunday night’s 119-110 loss to the Charlotte Hornets, he smiled.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: Putin’s Proxy Culture War
description: Russia seeks solidarity among haters of liberalism.
content: Recently I reached out to Serhiy Leshchenko, one of Ukraine’s most prominent investigative journalists, whom I’d met in Kyiv shortly before Donald Trump’s first impeachment. At the time, Leshchenko was being regularly smeared by people in Trump’s orbit who placed the journalist at the center of an elaborate conspiracy theory designed to make it look as if Trump was fighting corruption in Ukraine, not encouraging it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natalie Weiner
title: Stanford Wins a Rematch With Texas and a Trip to the Final Four
description: Stanford, a No. 1 seed, took one of its three losses this season in November against Texas, but it bested the Longhorns on Sunday to reach the national semifinals.
content: SPOKANE, Wash. — The reigning champions are back in the Final Four. No. 1-seeded Stanford beat No. 2 Texas, 59-50, on Sunday to reach its 15th N.C.A.A. tournament national semifinals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Guy Trebay
title: Will Smith Attends the 2022 Vanity Fair Oscars Party
description: Jessica Chastain, Zendaya and Timothée Chalamet also hit the annual celebration.
content: BEVERLY HILLS, Calif. — “In 20 years of coming, this is the most fun I’ve ever had,” Adrien Brody, the Oscar-winning actor, said at Vanity Fair’s annual Oscars party on Sunday. “I had real conversations, about politics, life and art.’’
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: verboten
description: This word has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word verboten has appeared in 19 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Feb. 5 in “Bringing Health Food to the Masses, One Delivery at a Time” by David Gelles:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anne Readel
title: In Wisconsin: Stowing Mowers, Pleasing Bees
description: Can the No Mow May movement help transform the traditional American lawn — a manicured carpet of grass — into something more ecologically beneficial?
content: As I drove last May through Appleton, Wis., the small town offered up a series of idyllic scenes: children playing on tree-lined streets, couples walking their dogs, and all the while, the wind carrying the sweetness of spring.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: Here’s the Neat Trick of Biden’s Billionaire Tax
description: How to convince the Supreme Court that the plan is constitutional?
content: President Biden is trying to pull off a neat trick with his so-called billionaire tax plan: to raise taxes on the wealthy without directly taxing wealth.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gina Cherelus and Gabriela Bhaskar
title: Are You ‘Mask Fishing’?
description: As some Covid anxieties have receded, teenagers have a new word for the fear of shedding their masks to reveal their faces.
content: Tanushri Sundaram, 17, thinks everyone at her school is a bit of a “mask fisher.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Supreme Court to Hear Copyright Fight Over Andy Warhol’s Images of Prince
description: The justices will decide whether the artist’s reliance on a photograph of the musician was copyright infringement or protected as a new, transformative work.
content: WASHINGTON — The Supreme Court agreed on Monday to decide whether Andy Warhol violated the copyright law by drawing on a photograph for a series of images of the musician Prince.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Return of the hosts: Amy Schumer, Regina Hall and Wanda Sykes got the show started. Here’s their full monologue.
description: The Oscars opener was a fast-paced avalanche of witty snipes and rapid-fire roasts.
content: After several years without a single host, the Oscars got going Sunday night with three of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marian Bull
title: A Family Is Delighted, and a Bit Surprised, to Move to Brooklyn
description: Longtime Manhattanites wanted to shorten their 8-year-old son’s commute to school. They found a stronger sense of community on the other side of the East River.
content: Over the 24 years of their relationship, Joseph Vitale and Robert Talmas have let their jobs dictate their real estate decisions. Work moved them from New Jersey to New York to Boston and back to New York. Mr. Talmas, now the head of compensation and benefits for WW (formerly Weight Watchers), spent a brief stint in Singapore. But as their family grew, those priorities changed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg and Nancy Wartik
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: Biden Stands by His Condemnation
description: Plus a strike roils India and the Academy Awards condemn Will Smith.
content: President Biden stood by his weekend comment that Vladimir Putin “cannot remain in power,” but said he was expressing “moral outrage,” not a policy change. He said no one should have thought his comments were meant to be calling for Putin’s ouster.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Roger Cohen
title: President Macron’s Unending Russia Diplomacy
description: The French leader’s outreach to his counterparts in Russia and Ukraine is stubborn. Whether it is also effective remains to be seen.
content: PARIS — Nobody can accuse President Emmanuel Macron of stinting on efforts to avert, defuse or stop Russia’s war in Ukraine. He has clocked 17 phone conversations with President Vladimir V. Putin in the past four months, one personal meeting in Moscow and so many hours of discussion with his own aides that he has had scant time for the small matter of a presidential election in less than two weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew E. Kramer and Steven Erlanger
title: Ukraine Claims Some Battle Successes as Russia Focuses on Another Front
description: With the fighting raging and sputtering attempts at diplomacy continuing, diplomacy between the two sides was continuing, with talks planned in Istanbul on Tuesday.
content: KYIV, Ukraine — Ukrainians on Monday reported that they had pushed back invading Russian forces in fierce fighting around Kyiv and in northeastern Ukraine, while the Russians moved to encircle and cut off Ukrainian forces in the east, making a diplomatic resolution to the war seem as far away as ever.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carole Landry
title: Biden's ‘Moral Outrage’
description: Biden said his remarks did not imply a policy to oust Vladimir Putin.
content: Good evening. This is your Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, a weeknight guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Bryan Avelar
title: Hundreds Arrested in El Salvador, Raising Fears of a Civil Liberties Crackdown
description: The Salvadoran government’s response to the weekend’s gang violence that left dozens dead is stoking fears that the emergency measures will allow President Nayib Bukele to further consolidate power.
content: María spent Monday looking for her 16-year-old son, checking various jails and juvenile detention centers with no luck — he was one of hundreds of people detained in the hours after a state of emergency took effect throughout El Salvador the day before.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Find Heritage Kulfi’s Intense Flavors at Kalustyan’s
description: The Manhattan store now stocks the brand’s frozen desserts, including saffron, rosewater and cardamom-chai options.
content: Kulfi, an Indian frozen dessert, is distinguished by its velvety texture and a density that comes from its having been churned only minimally, if at all. Heritage Kulfi, a new brand being introduced at the store Kalustyan’s, in Manhattan, comes in several intense and alluring flavors like saffron, rosewater and cardamom-chai. Earl Grey, Alphonso mango, pistachio, coconut and vanilla are the other flavors offered by the company founded by Mansoor Ahmed, an entrepreneur who is of Indian descent. The company, based in Princeton, N.J., developed a proprietary process to make the flavors soar.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The budget focuses on fighting inflation, but that’s mainly a Fed project.
description: The administration’s new budget suggests strategies for bringing down inflation, but many would take time to play out, or offer limited help.
content: Soaring consumer prices are undermining President Biden’s economic approval ratings, making inflation a critical topic for the White House headed into midterm elections — and making fighting it a focus of the administration’s budget, even though the Federal Reserve plays the primary role in countering rapid price increases.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Futterman
title: Kylie McKenzie Sues U.S.T.A., Claiming It Failed to Keep Her Safe
description: The tennis player claims the organization failed to disclose that her coach may have sexually assaulted one of its employees.
content: Kylie McKenzie, a once-promising tennis player whom an investigation found was “more likely than not” to have been sexually assaulted by a coach at a United States Tennis Association training center, filed a federal lawsuit against the organization on Monday, claiming it had failed to keep her safe from someone with a history of assaulting women.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Star Anchor Says Shift at Fox News Led to Exit
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, March 28, 2022.
content: “I think Fox has changed over the course of the last year and a half. But I can certainly understand where somebody would say, ‘Gee, you were a slow learner, Chris.’”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Karen Zraick and Ashley Wong
title: ‘High-Rise Hell’: N.Y.C. Skyscraper’s Elevator Breakdowns Strand Tenants
description: A luxury residential building in the financial district with more than 750 apartments has been experiencing lengthy elevator outages since the fall.
content: When it was completed in 1931, the City Bank-Farmers Trust Company Building towered over the financial district as one of the tallest buildings in New York City. It was, in fact, the tallest with a stone-clad facade, which featured 14 Assyrian-style busts, called “giants of finance,” watching over the narrow streets from their perch on the 19th floor. Replicas of coins from around the world adorned the entrance, representing countries where National City Bank — which would later become Citibank — had branches.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Vin Sur Vingt Adds a Wine Shop on the Upper West Side
description: The small chain of French wine bars opened Le French Wine Shop, which stocks only French wine.
content: Vin sur Vingt, a group of French wine bars in New York with a branch in Washington, D.C., has added an Upper West Side wine shop. Sébastien Auvet, the managing partner for the group, started a wine club connected to the bars a few years ago and has followed that program with this new resource. The store stocks only French wines, no spirits or aperitifs, and hundreds of them are arranged by region with most priced from $13 to $400. “French wine can be intimidating,” Mr. Auvet said. “We’re trying to democratize them.” The store, managed by Tucker Hurley, holds tastings several times a week and will offer subscriptions later this year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Biden’s budget proposal is set to include a tax on the richest Americans.
description: The White House on Monday will ask Congress to tax the top one-hundredth of 1 percent of American households.
content: When the White House makes its budget proposal on Monday, aiming to revitalize President Biden’s domestic agenda and reduce the deficit, it will ask Congress to pass a new minimum tax on billionaires, The Times’s Zolan Kanno-Youngs reports.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tony Scherman
title: Molly Tuttle Is a Top Bluegrass Guitarist. She’s Also a Lot More.
description: After two albums of roots pop, the musician returns to her own roots for “Crooked Tree,” an album that takes inspiration from her lifelong journey living with alopecia areata.
content: The singer, songwriter and guitarist Molly Tuttle’s fingers move so quickly, she could pick your pocket without breaking stride. Though she’s only been releasing albums for three years, the sharpest ears in Americana music have taken notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Russia’s new tactics in Ukraine.
content: In the second month of fighting, Russian forces have largely failed to take Ukraine’s largest cities and have narrowed immediate targets to the sieges of Mariupol, which appeared close to falling, and the strategically placed city of Chernihiv in the north. Follow the latest updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Stopping Creighton’s Charge, South Carolina Heads to the Final Four
description: The Bluejays had become the rare No. 10 seed to reach the round of 8, but top-seeded South Carolina proved too tough and advanced to its fourth national semifinal under Coach Dawn Staley.
content: GREENSBORO, N.C. — South Carolina, the top-seeded team in the women’s tournament, is heading to its fourth Final Four after defeating Creighton 80-50 on Sunday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: For Albert Pujols, One Last Run Where It All Began
description: After 11 seasons away, Pujols, 42, returns to the St. Louis Cardinals. “Oh, he’s got something left,” said his new manager.
content: JUPITER, Fla. — Adam Wainwright remembers precisely where he was on that sad December morning when the best hitter of his generation left the St. Louis Cardinals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Onstage Slap Rattles Oscars, Before ‘CODA’ Triumphs
description: On a night when “CODA” became the first film from a streaming service to win best picture, the focus was on Will Smith’s altercation with Chris Rock.
content: LOS ANGELES — In an Academy Awards ceremony where an onstage altercation between Will Smith and Chris Rock overshadowed the honors, “CODA” from Apple TV+ won the Oscar for best picture, becoming the first film from a streaming service to be welcomed into that rarefied Hollywood club.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Will Smith Owned the Williams Sisters’ Story Onscreen. Then He Stole Their Moment.
description: An Oscar night that should have affirmed Serena and Venus’s rise to stardom instead played out in a way they have seen before — triumph tempered by mixed emotions.
content: The table was set for a moment of family triumph. Venus and Serena Williams were dressed and seated for the grand occasion on Sunday night, and Will Smith, who had played their father Richard with uncanny similitude in the movie “King Richard,” was poised to win the Oscar for best actor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri
title: From ‘Illegal’ Hotel to Housing for the Homeless on Upper West Side
description: The Manhattan building used to attract tourists. But New York City officials hope its transformation is a road map for the city’s future.
content: The lobby of the Manhattan building once known as the Royal Park Hotel still beckons to tourists: A sign advertises cheap shuttle rides to nearby airports, and rows of pamphlets promote Broadway musicals and attractions like the Guggenheim Museum.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya King and Nick Corasaniti
title: Local Election Officials in Georgia Oppose G.O.P. Election Bill
description: As Republicans rush to pass a second round of new voting and election rules, a bipartisan group of election officials is fighting back.
content: ATLANTA — A year ago, when Georgia Republicans passed a mammoth law of election measures and voting restrictions, many local election officials felt frustrated and sidelined, as their concerns about resources, ballot access and implementation went largely ignored.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zach Montague and Alan Rappeport
title: Deficit would fall by $1 trillion over a decade under the proposed budget.
description: President Biden looks to win support from moderates and emphasizes fiscal responsibility.
content: President Biden’s 2023 budget request aims to shrink the federal budget deficit by $1 trillion over a decade as the administration looks to mitigate the impact of America’s yearslong borrowing binge.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Billy Witz
title: Final Four Snaps College Basketball Back to Reality
description: No more upstarts — only big-time programs are left in the running for the men’s national championship.
content: Since the clock struck midnight a couple weeks ago, marking the start of St. Patrick’s Day — and the moment when Notre Dame outlasted Rutgers in double overtime, sending its coach, Mike Brey, in search of some celebratory Irish whiskey — the madness of the N.C.A.A. tournament has returned this March.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Museum of Natural History’s New Science Center Takes Shape
description: On Monday, the museum unveiled the opening date of its Richard Gilder Center for Science, Education and Innovation and shared details of what it will contain.
content: In 2014, when the American Museum of Natural History first announced plans for a major expansion devoted to science, the museum president, Ellen V. Futter, talked about the “gap in the public understanding of science at the same time when many of the most important issues have science as their foundation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Stevens
title: Will Smith hits Chris Rock after joke about his wife, Jada.
description: The apparently unscripted moment stunned viewers and audiences alike. The telecast was muted and paused in the United States.
content: In an apparently unscripted moment that stunned viewers and audience members alike, Will Smith strode onstage and hit Chris Rock in the face after the comedian made a joke about the actor’s wife while presenting the best documentary award at the Oscars.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Das
title: U.S. Thrashes Panama and Pencils Itself Into the World Cup
description: Christian Pulisic led the way with three goals, but the Americans still must go to Costa Rica to guarantee their place in Qatar.
content: The United States men’s soccer team is not in the World Cup, not just yet. There is still one last trip to make, one last job to do, one last game to play.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicole Daniels and Michael Gonchar
title: What Role Does Religion Play in Your Life?
description: Did you attend religious services or observe religious traditions as a child? How has religion shaped who you are today?
content: When you were younger, did you attend religious services or participate in religious observations with your family? Did you belong to any kind of religious community? What about now, as a teenager?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sheera Frenkel
title: FedEx’s founder, Fred Smith, will step down as C.E.O.
description: Raj Subramaniam, the current president and chief operating officer, will succeed Mr. Smith, according to a news release issued by FedEx.
content: Fifty years after he founded the company, Frederick Smith announced on Monday that he will step down as FedEx’s chief executive in June.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clare Toeniskoetter, Stella Tan, Kaitlin Roberts, Mike Benoist, Lisa Tobin, Marion Lozano, Elisheba Ittoop, Dan Powell and Chris Wood
title: Four Million Ukrainians in Limbo
description: We follow Iryna, one of those scrambling to find refuge after the Russian invasion.
content: Since the beginning of Russia’s war in Ukraine, 10 million Ukrainians — about a quarter of the population — have been displaced, and about four million have fled the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joan Suazo and Anatoly Kurmanaev
title: Honduran Supreme Court Ratifies U.S. Extradition Request of Ex-President
description: The former leader of Honduras is accused of colluding with drug cartels to ship tons of cocaine to the United States in return for financial support for his political party.
content: TEGUCIGALPA, Honduras — The Honduran Supreme Court ratified on Monday the United States’ extradition request for the former president, Juan Orlando Hernández, setting the stage for what could become the highest profile drug trafficking case in New York since the trial of the Mexican cartel chief Joaquín Guzmán, known as El Chapo.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A Spring Salad Bowl With a MoMA Pedigree
description: This stainless steel serving ware insulates well and comes with nesting servers.
content: Springtime demands a fitting salad: A frilly tangle of greens traced with a light vinaigrette and strewn with fresh cuts of radish, cucumber, green onion and the like. A bright new bowl to set off this inviting splendor is a newcomer in the MoMA Design Store. It’s in a mirror-finish stainless steel, and, at 10 inches in diameter, will comfortably serve two to four. The double-wall construction insulates, so raw ingredients keep their cool and heated food, like potatoes or pasta, stay warm, and it comes with sleek nesting serving utensils. It’s not too soon to think Mother’s Day.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: With a center-leaning budget, Biden bows to political reality.
description: The president’s budget addresses the main attack lines that Republicans are using against him and his Democratic allies in Congress in the run-up to midterm congressional elections.
content: With his party facing potentially gale-force headwinds in the midterm elections, President Biden released a budget on Monday that tacks toward the political center, bowing to the realities facing endangered Democrats by bolstering defense and law enforcement spending and tackling inflation and deficit reduction in service of what he called a “bipartisan unity agenda.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maya Phillips
title: Review: ‘Confederates’ Talks Race in Double Time
description: In Dominique Morisseau’s promising new play, the action is in the ideas and the setting bounces between the Civil War era and the present.
content: “This play is not like all of my others,” Dominique Morisseau writes in an author’s note in the script for “Confederates.” The new play, about two Black women living in different times but dealing with similar oppression, carries several signatures of Morisseau’s work and yet uses narrative techniques that are departures for her. It makes sense then that “Confederates,” which opened on Sunday at the Pershing Square Signature Theater, feels like an elegant experiment, thoughtful and put-together but not quite realizing its full potential.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear
title: ‘I Make No Apologies’: Biden Says His Putin Comments Were an Expression of Moral Outrage
description: President Biden said his words, delivered in a speech over the weekend in Warsaw, were not a call for regime change in Russia.
content: WASHINGTON — President Biden on Monday stood by his comment that Vladimir V. Putin should not remain president of Russia, but he said it was an expression of his own horror over the invasion of Ukraine and not a change in American policy aimed at seeking to remove Mr. Putin from office.
source.name: The New York Times

description: The Times’s Visual Investigations team analyzed dozens of battlefield radio transmissions between Russian forces during an initial invasion of the town of Makariv in Ukraine.

title: Is Covid Sparing Africans? The Mystery Matters.
description: On a recent reporting trip to Sierra Leone, I came across a crowded soccer match, a rock concert and a huge wedding. No one had a mask on. But I didn’t find any Covid cases at the hospital. People said, there’s no Covid here.

title: Pennsylvania Snow Squall Causes Highway Pileup
description: Sudden and blinding snow caused at least 50 vehicles to crash on Interstate 81 northeast of Harrisburg, Pa. About 20 people were taken to hospitals, the authorities said.

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Blacken Your Fish, Please
description: Try Vallery Lomas’s fish and grits, Ligaya Mishan’s version of a classic Middle Eastern lentil stew, and more recipes.
content: Good morning. The day after I failed to catch a tarpon in the backwaters of Everglades National Park in Florida last week, I ate a blackened redfish sandwich on the porch of the Rod and Gun Club in Everglades City. It wasn’t a particularly spicy version of the preparation Paul Prudhomme popularized in the 1980s. But it came on a soft roll with a fat, glistening slice of Immokalee tomato, some chilled lettuce, raw white onion and a spray of pickles, and I ate it happily in the breeze coming off the Barron River, washing everything down with iced tea.
source.name: The New York Times
